definition: One of the four pillars of OOP, this solves the problem of redundant code by allowing more specific versions of a class to use an existing implementation of fields/methods
One of the four pillars of OOP, this removes the need for messy, long if/else blocks by letting child classes define their own variations on parent behavior as needed
One of the four pillars of OOP, this hides details and complexity from other interacting classes to both simplify and organize code
One of the four pillars of OOP, this focuses on organizing each class's fields and methods so that each class only needs to worry about its own data and actions necessary to exist
Java keyword which disambiguates an object's fields when method parameters have the same name
Java keyword indicating a method returns nothing
Java keyword for a (i) class that can't be instantiated or (ii) a method whose implementation isn't defined in said class
SQL keyword used to re-combine tables, usually with one table's foreign key linking together with another table's primary key
SQL keyword indicating a shared column name in joins, used as a logical connection between the tables
SQL phrase indicating a column whose value will determine the sorting order
SQL keyword used to specify which columns should be included in a query
Java access modifier keyword which allows any class access to a field or method
Coding structure which allows the developer to define specific behavior in preparation of a likely error during runtime
A method used to create a new object of a particular class
A blueprint for a logical grouping of methods and fields
What SDLC is heavily structured and resistant to change?
A modifier used for classes, variables, and methods, which makes them non-changeable (impossible to inherit or override)
It is an instance of a class
It defines the common variables and methods of a set of objects
